body: I think it's the DNS issue since 0.7.12
Why would that affect Linux? Is there some Android here? @jpjp `STTRACE=discovery,connections` please :)
Probably replied while drunk with one eye closed, ignore me.

:) Regardless, there is some merit to the complaint. I have two of my devices that have real difficulties connecting to each other. What looks to be happening now is some race condition in the "switching connection" logic.
- Connection is established via relay for some reason related to connection attempts in one direction timing out
- A real connection is established later
- Device `A` closes the relay connection and begins negotiating on the real connection
- Device `B` removes the relay connection as it was closed, then hits the "switching connections" logic and closes the _real_ connection
- Devices end up disconnected, `goto 10`
I'd like to see the logs from both sides.

https://gist.github.com/calmh/220cbbdceb4c7788b075707ac7732127

It's unfiltered so there's some other crap. You want to look at the connection attempts between 4OODC and AFQDM. When the log begins they are connected via relay and I have just fixed a firewall that prevented a direct connection over IPv6 from one direction to the other.

At 10:16:53 the connection gets established AFQDM->4OODC and the switching logic happens, but the newly established connection gets dropped as well for some reason, by 4OODC at 10:16:56 from the looks of it, which is where I suspect a bug in the switching stuff.

Then things get successfully established on the next try, maybe since there wasn't already at relay connection at that point so no switching troubles. But I'm just guessing.
...and I can't reproduce the problem any more, despite being hit by it lots recently :/

So you are right, s.connType never goes through a delete() statement, so it probably always thinks it's connected.

Also there is a race between model.AddConnection and s.connType[deviceID] = newConnectionType, and the connect routine reading s.connType

I just had this happen again, and without debugging on, again :-/

If my public ip changes, syncthing permanently loses its connection to external nodes. All nodes on the local network continue to work.
Well that's probably todo with discovery breaking at that point, because IP is no longer valid.
If those connections are incoming only, yeah. It'll reannounce to the discovery server in half an hour or so - is "permanently" longer than that?
It got to 12 hours before I restarted it.

That's odd. The connections that do succeed, are the incoming our outgoing (from the perspective of the thing behind the changed IP address)? Sounds like there could be an actual issue there somewhere.

The nodes on the internet also lost connection to this machine that changed ip.

So both machine on the lan routing through this gateway machine with a changed ip lost all connection to outside nodes, and all outside nodes connecting directly to the gateway machine lost connectivity.
I think it will be something todo with discovery.
